TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She was represented before the Court by Ms M. Kuznetsova , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by Mr P. Laptev , Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

Before DATE the applicant , a NORP national , lived in GPE , GPE . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant together with her husband and CARDINAL children ( born in DATE and DATE ) left GPE for GPE due to the outbreak of an armed conflict in the region .

At first they stayed with the applicant ’s mother in GPE , but shortly after that moved to GPE . They remained registered at her mother ’s address . In DATE the applicant started to work as a school teacher . The school director requested the municipal authorities to provide the applicant with accommodation .
On DATE the Chief of ORG of GPE decided that the applicant should be provided with housing as soon as it would become available .

On DATE the applicant was temporarily allotted a CARDINAL - room apartment . The municipal housing service opened a personal account on the applicant ’s name for the purpose of billing the communal charges . The applicant moved in with her family , lived there and regularly paid all charges . She applied to the housing authorities to have a social tenancy established in respect of this apartment , but this was refused .
In DATE the residence block , including the applicant ’s flat , was placed at the disposal of the Moscow Migration Centre to be converted into dwellings for forced migrants .
On DATE ORG brought eviction proceedings against the applicant on the grounds that her occupancy was not lawful .

On DATE ORG of GPE ordered that temporary occupants , including the applicant , vacate the flats . The applicant was advised to apply to ORG to be provided with free housing . The school administration was also informed that the employment of staff members who were not registered in GPE was unlawful .
In DATE the applicant was dismissed from her job as a school teacher on the grounds that she had no officially registered address in GPE .

On DATE the applicant applied to the migration authorities of GPE to be granted the status of a forced migrant . She indicated that her permanent address was at her mother ’s house in GPE . On DATE the applicant was granted the status of a forced migrant for the period until DATE .
On DATE the applicant applied to ORG to be registered as a forced migrant . She also applied to ORG to be registered at the flat in GPE as her official address .

On DATE ORG of GPE examined the prosecutor ’s eviction claim and rejected it having found that the applicant had had a de facto tenancy contract . This judgment entered into force on DATE but was subsequently reversed in supervisory review proceedings . The case was re - examined in CARDINAL sets of civil proceedings before the final decision was taken on DATE ( see below ) .
On DATE ORG of the ORG authorised the applicant and her children to be temporarily registered at the disputed flat for DATE .
On DATE ORG advised the applicant that she could not be registered with them as a forced migrant until she cancels her registration with the migration authorities of LOC .

On DATE the applicant applied to the migration authorities of GPE to have her registration with them annulled and her file to be transferred to the GPE migration authorities . On DATE her request was granted .

On DATE the applicant was informed that she could not be registered with the GPE migration authorities because her official address remained in LOC . On DATE the applicant reiterated her request for registration as a forced migrant in GPE , which was refused on DATE because the applicant had provided no proof of her of official address in GPE . The applicant did not challenge the refusal .

On DATE the ORG gave the final decision authorising the applicant ’s eviction without providing her with substitute housing . It was established in the proceedings that the applicant ’s occupancy was not based on social tenancy , as she had never been issued a “ residence order ” or offered to sign a tenancy contract . The courts also found that the applicant had no status of a forced migrant on the basis of which she could claim social housing .
On DATE the applicant was served with an eviction order , but she did not comply with it .
On DATE the municipal service required the applicant to vacate the flat , but she did not do so .

In DATE the applicant was served with another eviction order , which she again did not comply with . Her eviction has not been enforced and , according to the latest updates , she continues to occupy the flat .

On DATE ORG of ORG decided that the disputed flat should be rented out to the applicant under a common tenancy contract . The applicant was invited to sign the contract and to complete the formalities .

The applicant refused to sign the common tenancy contract as it required her to pay rent , supposedly at the market rate which she thought would be too expensive for her . She believed to have been entitled to social housing by virtue of her previous occupancy , due to being a “ de facto refugee ” and a teacher , and being in need of state support .
The parties provided no details of the common tenancy contract offered to the applicant .
On DATE the applicant received a reminder to settle the tenancy rent , which she refuses to comply with .

Article CARDINAL of LAW in force at the material time provided that tenancy in the publicly owned LOC could only be validated by a documentary residence order issued by the local executive council . The form of the residence order was adopted by a governmental decree . LAW provided for eviction of persons occupying LOC without due permission .
According to LAW , dated DATE , No . CARDINAL - CARDINAL , persons registered as forced migrants may be provided with temporary accommodation in the specially allocated residence .
